entry.title: Combined summary - Re: Unbreaking testnet4
entry.summary: The recent update to the Bitcoin Core code, which focuses on addressing a specific problem within testnet4, has garnered attention from the cryptocurrency development community. This modification involved disabling the minimum difficulty rule following block 150,000. Despite being a minimal change, its significance lies in its potential impact on the network's functionality. The details of this adjustment can be found in a fork of the Bitcoin Core repository, available for viewing [here](https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/compare/master.batmanbytes:bitcoin:testnet4-fix). Additionally, a comprehensive discussion providing more insight into the rationale and expected outcomes of this tweak is accessible on [Bitcointalk](https://bitcointalk.org/index.php?topic=5569103.msg66301279msg66301279). This change is anticipated to increase the interval time between blocks starting from block 149,184, which initiates the epoch that includes block 150,000. The adjustment comes as a solution to the predicted rise in block generation time to about one hour per block due to the effective hashrate dropping significantly. This drop is primarily because the mentioned epoch is expected to produce a considerably higher number of difficulty-1 blocks than those generated under standard conditions. The conversation among developers and the community also touches on the possibility of further code modifications to mitigate the temporary extension of block interval times based on feedback and observed network behaviors. Moreover, an additional perspective provided highlights a broader context of testnet4's performance, mentioning the overproduction of approximately 30,000 blocks relative to the expected number since the genesis block. It points out that even if the difficulty re-adjustment takes three months instead of the usual two weeks, the impact might be negligible considering the surplus of around 1.5 million coins already in existence. However, concerns were raised regarding the rejection of all blocks with CPU difficulty, as it could lead to network stagnation when ASIC miners temporarily increase the difficulty and subsequently exit, leaving the network unable to progress. These discussions underscore the ongoing efforts to refine Bitcoinâ€™s test networks and demonstrate the collaborative nature of open-source development within the cryptocurrency community. The openness to adjustments based on community feedback and observed outcomes shows a commitment to enhancing the network's robustness and functionality.
